SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name ... William Gladstone Mason ("Sam")
2. Your address ... R.R.5 ... Langley Prairie ... B.C.
3. Date ... July 13, 1953
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Dundas, Ontario

5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   William Mason - Farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   July 19, 1887

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   Dundas, Ont. ... Erin, Bruce County, Ont.
   1878 - 1882 ... 1882 - 1889

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc).
   11 years

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   Parents came west to take up land

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information)?
    Thomas Spence - formerly of Walkerton, Bruce County had taken a homestead land 3 miles South on Alberta one year previously & reported opportunity in the West. Also sent samples of land East for analysis.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct or you have given it, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing as you see this question, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: William Gladstone Mason (C. Sam)

2. Your address: R.R.5, Henry Roy Provincial Road, B.C.

3. Date: July 13, 1953

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Almada, Bolivia

5. What was your father's name and occupation? William Mason - Farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) July 19, 1887

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates whenever possible. Brundoo, Ont., Bonaviklin, Beaver County, Ont.

8. How old were you when you first came to Eastern Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use it as a small skill.)

"I was in my teens," etc.

9. What were your reasons for coming North?

Parents came west & took up land

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroads or Government Information?)

Homestead Service - formerly of Walkerton, Bruce County

Had taken a homestead parcel 3 miles South of Alberts

One year previously & reported opportunity in the West also sent sampling seed & soil for analysis.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   Tried to stop such a foolish undertaking

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   Two families traveled by rail road
   Mr. Hos Lockhart family & Wm Mason family

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   Railway

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   Nothing unusual remembered
   Five day trip - tourist car with stove
   At one end I bed up over head
   On our arrival in Regina my people and us children went looking for a house to rent. We went to a house that was empty on Hamilton St., which close to where City Hall grounds are north east corner looked by a window. Doors were locked, and found a man dead hanging by the neck from ceiling by small short rope
   I did not rent that house.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   Found a cottage to rent owned by Mr. Archie Mc Dougald where Bible Institute Bldg is formerly Clayton Hotel

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   S.E. '4' 16 16 19

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   Bladworth, Grenfell, Bemersayle, Bengough, Sask
   Moved to Langley Prairie, B.C. in 1944

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
   Child at home
   First work helped paddle city water horse & cart filling private containers
   Broke & seed brown for Geo Hartley. Supplied hay & oats
   Steamer for horses used on Scopes widening creek into Wasana lake
   Homesteaded & farmed South of Regina
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

This plan had been made at Rail Head.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Railway

14. What incidents of the Journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences etc.)

Nothing unusual remembered.

Give day trip - Turned back on 21st.

At one end a bed up each road.

On our arrival in Regina my people and children went looking for a house to rent and went to a house that was empty on Hamilton Street, but when we got there the city hall grounds and heard loud noises. Later by a window on the second floor and found a man about hanging just like he was not well at home.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Found a house to rent owned by Mr. Smith.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

S.E. 1/4 16 16 19

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Blakely, Strathcona, Bemidji, Bemidji, Sault Ste. Marie & Kamsack Province.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Worked at homestead, plowed grey water drain, coal, fell logs, purchased cattle, bought hay & oat.

Broke a sod house for the Honley. Supplied hay & oat.

Stationed for homestead on Sprague ward near east side of Wascoona Lake. Homesteaded 9 farms near Sault Ste. Marie.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
Family wrote regularly.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage:
Married Mary Edna Story - Dec 14, 1904 at Regina, Saskatchewan.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
Thomas Lockhart came to Saskatchewan because he heard about the land and decided to move there.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
Adopted sister Mrs John Carter & family - Settled in Saskatchewan - Mr & Mrs Wesley arrived 2 sons & daughter - settled Nov 6, 17, 19 - arrived here 1891 (south of Regina).

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
Yes, where bought in a blizzard Feb 14 - winter 1898? near Wascana, country club is now situated. Ponies & sleigh - Sam Mason, Syd Nelson, John Lockhart, 10 yrs. Lured ponies loose hoping they would go home to the barn. Would follow ponies. Stayed by sleigh & passed through snow to eat grass by sleigh. The boys used grain sacks & a quilt to form a shelter from storms. Survived by daylight, boys could see the Allan Morton home & were able to find their way to the house. Sleight was buried under a snow bank & was not found until April 19th when snow melted.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
Just local travelling by horseback or wagon.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

   Bought in a big yard Feb. 14 - winter 1898-99

25. When was the first car used in the community? Saw first Car 1907 in district
   Stuck in mud 11 miles S & Regina W G Mason pulled it out
   with a team of horses - owned by "Fanny" Arnold, Regina

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   No

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Regina 8 miles

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Yes

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   Weekly

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   From earliest remembrance, so that horses could rest on Sunday

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since then.
   Clothing bought from J. Eaton's Toronto
   From 1904

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   Not known

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   Came here & Homestead with parents

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

School Trustee at Davidson and Grenfell, Sask.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

about 1892 - first flowing well located on S.E. 1/4 28-16-19 was found on farm Homestead of Wm. Mason about a 1/4 mile from the present flowing well located on road allowance between Sections 28 & 21 Township No. R. 19. First well stopped flowing when second one was drilled near.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Springdale School was named after Wm. Mason farm. Mrs. Wm. Mason called the farm Springdale farm. Zithydorf Colony consisting of 18 families were settled on 40 acres of Section 21-16-19 at the site of the present flowing well.
